FOR  
 
STRENGTHENING POVERTY ANALYSIS 
 
AND STRATEGIES IN THE PACIFIC 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
December 2003

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  MDG  –  Millennium Development Goal 
  NGO  –  nongovernment organization 
  PARD  –  Pacific Department 
  PDMC  –  Pacific developing member country 
  PPA  –  participatory poverty assessment 
  PRISM  –  Pacific Regional Information System 
  RETA  –  regional technical assistance 
  SPC  –  Secretariat of the Pacific Community 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 This report was prepared by M. Prokop, Pacific Department.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  At a donors’ meeting held in Sydney in June 2002, major funding agencies to the Pacific 
countries  discussed  their  approaches  to  identifying  and  addressing  poverty.  The  agencies 
agreed to an Asian Development Bank (ADB) suggestion that a coordinated regional approach 
to poverty analysis would be more cost effective and efficient than each agency working in 
isolation. Participants agreed that ADB would take the lead in coordinating efforts to design a 
Pacific fund for strategic poverty analysis. ADB subsequently secured funding from the Poverty 
Reduction Cooperation Fund to examine the feasibility and potential scope of the proposed 
multi-agency activity.1 
 
2.  The  study  consulted  extensively  with  stakeholders  in  the  Pacific  Island  countries, 
development partners, and regional institutions to (i) assess the feasibility of a poverty fund; (ii) 
agree on essential procedures, location, and management structure; and (iii) suggest types of 
activities the fund might undertake. A draft report was presented at the regional Millennium 
Development Goal (MDG) workshop in Nadi, Fiji Islands, in March 2003, and subsequently 
distributed  for  further  comment  to  governments,  nongovernment  organizations  (NGOs), 
development  partners,  and  regional  organizations.  While  the  feasibility  study  referred  to  a 
"fund," discussions with stakeholders acknowledged that a fund is not the only mechanism for 
improving donor coordination, and that a coordinated program (the Program) may allow more 
flexibility. At a follow-up to a regional donors' meeting in Sydney in July 2003, ADB, Australian 
Agency for International Development, New Zealand Agency for International Development, and 
the World Bank reached substantial agreement on the concept for the Program, and agreed that 
ADB would prepare a concept paper reflecting the agreement, for further consideration and 
discussion.  The  concept  paper  was  presented  and  discussed  at  the  Thirteenth  Regional 
Meeting of Heads of Statistics in Noumea, New Caledonia, on 15–19 September 2003, and 
received widespread support. ADB agreed to initiate the Program through technical assistance 
(TA) while continuing its involvement in consultations with other agencies regarding their future 
contributions to the Program. Funding for the TA from the Poverty Reduction Cooperation Fund 
and  the  Cooperation  Fund  in  Support  of  the  Formulation  and  Implementation  of  National 
Poverty Reduction Strategies was endorsed at the 2nd Strategy Meeting in December 2002. The 
TA’s goals, purpose, and scope are summarized in the TA framework (Appendix 1).2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Until recently, poverty in the Pacific developing member countries (PDMCs) did not 
command as much attention as in most other developing countries partly because most Pacific 
societies consider that traditional support mechanisms provide for the vulnerable, and partly 
because of political sensitivities to the issue.3 There is growing evidence of rising poverty and 
hardship levels in many PDMCs due to two decades of weak economic performance, and 
associated  with  rapid  population  growth,  urban  drift,  and  weakening  traditional  support 
mechanisms.4  With  the  countries'  commitments  to  achieve  the  MDGs,  governments  are

increasingly aware of the importance of addressing poverty or hardship reduction. To do so, 
countries will need to (i) collect, analyze, and disseminate the data required to assess poverty; 
(ii) develop the human and institutional capacities to use the data to develop poverty reduction 
policies in a participatory manner; and (iii) monitor progress toward achievement of the MDGs.  
 
4.  The six participatory studies of the priorities of the poor, or people in hardship, that ADB 
has completed so far all point, very clearly and consistently, to two priority areas that define 
poverty or hardship in the region: (i) the need to improve access to, and delivery of, essential 
social  services,  primary  education,  and  primary  healthcare;  and  (ii)  improved  access  to 
commercial markets to sell produce and services and to secure formal jobs.5 Existing statistical 
data  bases  and  regional  efforts  such  as  the  General  Data  Dissemination  System  do  not 
adequately focus on analyzing and monitoring these priorities. 
 
5.  While the capacity of the individual PDMCs in data collection and analysis varies, most 
governments and NGO representatives acknowledged that capacity needs to be enhanced 
despite many years of such effort. Most PDMCs have conducted either a census or a household 
survey within the last 5 years (Appendix 2). The analyses of surveys and poverty assessments 
have mostly been carried out under externally financed initiatives and by external consultants, 
with limited skill transfer and minimal confidence building in poverty analysis. As a result, the 
PDMCs’ capacities to analyze social data for poverty measurements and the demand for and 
ownership of such assessments have not been strengthened. Often, the problem is not so much 
a lack of data but one of quality and consistency of data and a lack of capacity to use it. Many 
countries have substantial administrative data, currently underused for poverty assessments, 
partly due to the lack of appropriate communication and coordination links between national 
statistical offices, statistics offices in line ministries, and national planning departments. Data 
from  many  surveys  cannot  be  compared  with  that  from  other  key  sources,  due  to 
inconsistencies  between  survey  design  and  indicators  used,  incomplete  complementarity 
between  questions,  and  the  use  of  unrepresentative  samples.  Data  dissemination  and 
maintenance pose an additional problem. Of further concern is the lack of prioritization of 
national development strategies in most PDMCs on issues of concern to the poor, and the lack 
of implementation of programs and policies. 
 
6.  Most stakeholders consulted during the feasibility study stressed the commitment of the 
Secretariat of the Pacific Community (SPC) to the region's development, and its extensive 
experience in capacity building in social and economic statistics in the PDMCs, and suggested 
that SPC be the executing agency for the Pacific Poverty Program. The Social Resources 
Division of SPC combines the statistics, demography and population, public health, women, 
youth, reproductive health, and community education programs. The division is therefore in an 
excellent position to ensure that the TA benefits from this multi-disciplinary expertise. SPC is 
also currently carrying out complementary projects such as the Pacific regional information  
system (PRISM) project, and a population geographic information system project. ADB has 
worked successfully on several projects with SPC.6

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
 
7.  The goal of the TA is to assist PDMCs to develop the capacity to formulate pro-poor 
strategies and budgets in a participatory manner, thereby enabling them to reduce poverty and 
achieve progress toward the MDGs. The short- and medium-term objectives of the TA are to 
enhance the capacity and demand, within government  and civil society, for the collection, 
analysis, and effective use of consistent and high quality data related to poverty and hardship.  
 
8.   The TA will facilitate consultation with stakeholders and initiate the establishment of the 
Program as the main information-sharing and coordination mechanism for regional poverty data 
collection, analysis, and monitoring activities. The TA will encourage the contribution of other 
development partners to the Program in order to build on, expand, and extend the TA activities. 
 
9.  The scope of activities of the TA will initially focus on the short- and medium-term 
objectives  with  a  view  to  expanding  the  scope  of  activities  depending  on  demand  and 
contributions of other agencies to the Program. The TA framework contains a detailed list of 
outputs. Outputs will be further defined after the needs of the individual PDMCs have been 
assessed. 
 
10.  The quality of surveys and analyses that relate to poverty will be strengthened by (i) 
ensuring  that  each  PDMC  has  at  least  one  reasonably  recent  good  quality  census  and 
household survey; (ii) providing funds for adding components that focus on poverty or hardship 
to  routine  surveys;  (iii)  assisting  in  the  questionnaire  design,  ensuring  consistency,  and 
harmonizing definitions, particularly those related to MDGs; (iv) providing quality assurance for 
survey design and implementation, including implications for sample design of the need for 
appropriate subnational estimates; and (v) ensuring that adequate attention is given to sex-
disaggregated data, and, where appropriate, ethnicity-disaggregated data. 
 
11.  Capacity  will  be  strengthened  and  built  for  participatory  poverty  assessments.  The 
assessments will focus on community perception and priorities to provide government and 
development partners with directions for policy and program development. Capacity will also be 
strengthened for (i) better use of available data, particularly administrative data, for poverty 
analyses;  and  (ii)  using  the  data  to  develop  strategies  for  equitable  growth  and  hardship 
alleviation, and linking these to national development strategies. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  The TA builds on work of earlier regional TA, and work conducted by other agencies 
related to poverty data collection and analysis. It will benefit from the synergies with current 
activities in the region. The TA will commence with the development of a paper providing 
direction for governments and societies of PDMCs on how to address prioritization of national 
development and poverty reduction strategies, particularly with respect to the priorities of the 
poor, and their need for improved access to basic social services and employment creation.This 
work will be based on quantitative and qualitative poverty assessments conducted by ADB 
under several technical assistance projects.7

4 
 
13.  TA  activities  will  emphasize  (i)  strengthening  the  demand  for  poverty  statistics  to 
enhance ownership and sustainability by fostering greater participation of civil society in data 
collection, poverty analysis, monitoring, and evaluation; (ii) focusing all activities funded by the 
TA, such as support for surveys, participatory poverty assessments, and poverty analysis, as 
well  as  the  development  of  policy  responses,  on  capacity  building  and  institutional 
strengthening;  (iii)  where  available,  providing  technical  support  using  local  and  regional 
consultants; and (iv)  building a regional database of local consultants. 
 
14.   The scope of the TA activities is expected to expand once the Program is established 
and more development partners provide contributions. Some of the key activities that the TA will 
support are the assessment of (i) poverty data collection and analysis related activities in the 
PDMCs (on a country and regional level); the assessment will be updated regularly, reported on 
a six-monthly basis to all relevant agencies, and disseminated via the PRISM network; (ii) 
available data, and data analysis and capacity needs (related to poverty and the priorities 
expressed by the poor), in order to develop work programs for each PDMC; and (iii) the 
coordination of data users (e.g., national planning offices) and data producers (e.g., national 
statistical offices and line ministries) and suggestions to improve the coordination. 
 
15.  The assessments will identify the priorities for the TA activities. The TA will focus on (i) 
countries that have not been covered by previous poverty assessments under TA 6002 and 
6047 (footnote 7), and (ii) PDMCs that show strong commitment and ownership. This will 
include participatory poverty assessments with capacity building for Cook Islands, Kiribati, and 
Solomon Islands; improvement of the quality and poverty focus of household surveys for Cook 
Islands, Kiribati, Papua New Guinea, and Tuvalu; and general data quality improvement as a 
regional activity. Funding for activities that were identified as priorities in the assessments but 
cannot be covered by the TA will be sought from other development partners. 
 
16.  Other key activities include: (i) defining poverty and hardship related data in consultation 
with stakeholders; the information collected during the participatory poverty assessments will 
help to guide what type of data should be collected; (ii) supporting, in coordination with United 
Nations  Development  Programme  and  other  relevant  agencies,  the  monitoring  of  MDGs 
including the discussion of the relevance and determination of indicators and targets appropriate 
for PDMCs; and (iii) reviewing, with the participation of civil society organizations and PDMC 
governments, lessons learned during implementation of TA, and preparing a revised Program 
document based on lessons learned and disseminating it to all stakeholders. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
17.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $1.15 million equivalent, with an amount not 
exceeding  the  equivalent  of  $800,000  to  be  financed  on  a  grant  basis  from  the  Poverty 
Reduction Cooperation Fund and the Cooperation Fund in Support of the Formulation and 
Implementation of National Poverty Reduction Strategies, each for $400,000 equivalent. ADB 
will provide $200,000 on a grant basis from ADB's TA funding program. The Executing Agency 
will provide the balance of $150,000 equivalent through in-kind contributions. The governments 
of PDMCs will provide counterpart support for in-country activities. Detailed cost estimates and 
the financing plan are provided in Appendix 3.

D.  Implementation Arrangements 
18.  The Executing Agency of the TA is the Social Resources Division of SPC in Noumea, 
New Caledonia. Two international consultants (a poverty specialist and development economist 
and a social analyst and participatory poverty assessment specialist) will be selected by SPC 
after appropriate consultation with ADB, including preparing terms of reference and evaluation 
criteria. They will be recruited on an individual basis in accordance with ADB's Guidelines on the 
Selection of Consultants for a total period of 23 person-months. The two consultants will be 
based at SPC. Other international or domestic consultants will be selected and recruited by 
SPC as needed in accordance with ADB's Guidelines on the Selection of Consultants, and other 
arrangements  satisfactory  to  ADB  for  the  engagement  of  domestic  consultants,  and  after 
appropriate consultation with ADB. 
 
19.   One international consultant (development economist) will be recruited by ADB for 2 
person-months to produce a poverty priorities strategy paper, and one domestic consultant will 
be based at ADB for the duration of the TA. The two consultants will be recruited by ADB as 
individuals  in  accordance  with  its  Guidelines  on  the  Selection  of  Consultants,  and  other 
arrangements satisfactory to ADB for the engagement of domestic consultants. All consultants 
will be nationals of ADB member countries, and ADB funding will be confined to benefiting 
PDMCs. The outline terms of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 4. The TA will be 
executed over a period of 24 months, and is expected to commence in February 2004 and be 
completed by March 2006. 
 
20.  SPC will prepare half-yearly reports on its activities for submission to ADB, and will 
consult on arrangements for workshops, seminars, and training, and the hiring of short-term and 
local consultants. SPC will also prepare a half-yearly update on poverty data collection, and 
analysis activities in the region. The update will be disseminated on the PRISM web site, and 
distributed to all relevant agencies, PDMCs, and NGOs. The team leader will provide a final 
report with recommendations and lessons learned during TA implementation. ADB will monitor 
the TA progress through review missions and through consultations with other development 
partners. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) ADB 
administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $800,000 to be 
financed on a grant basis by the Poverty Reduction Cooperation Fund and the Cooperation 
Fund  in  Support  of  the  Formulation  and  Implementation  of  National  Poverty  Reduction 
Strategies, each for $400,000 equivalent; and (ii) ADB providing the balance not exceeding the 
equivalent of $200,000 on a grant basis for Strengthening Poverty Analysis and Strategies in 
the Pacific, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
 
A.  Consultants Based at the Secretariat of the Pacific Community (SPC) 
 
1.  Poverty Specialist and Development Economist (15 person-months) 
 
1.  The specialist will be based in the Social Services Division of the Secretariat of the 
Pacific  Community  (SPC).  The  specialist  will  coordinate  activities  related  to  poverty  data 
collection and analysis in the Pacific region and provide overall guidance to the technical 
assistance (TA) activities and to the potential expansion of activities if further funding is received 
from other agencies for the Pacific poverty data program. 
 
2.  Experience and qualifications required of the specialist include:
